channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Facing Arrest, Musharraf Flees Pakistani Courtroom
item.description: Pervez Musharraf, a former military leader, was brought back to court a day after his dramatic escape after a judge revoked his bail.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: The convoy carrying Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan’s former leader, left the court on Thursday.

item.title: The Lede: Nurses Sought in Beatings at Russian Orphanage
item.description: Three residents of an orphanage, the oldest just 3 years old, were severely injured, drawing new attention to the plight of orphans in Russia.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ

item.title: Case Against Mexican Ex-Defense Official Collapses
item.description: Tomás Ángeles Dauahare, a former high-ranking defense ministry general charged with drug ties, walked free late Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Guatemala: Judge Says Testimony in Genocide Trial Must Be Repeated
item.description: A Guatemalan judge ruled Thursday that all the testimony in the genocide trial of the former dictator Efraín Ríos Montt, 86, was invalid and would have to be repeated.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Attacks Kill at Least 30
item.description: A suicide bomber detonated explosives at a Baghdad cafe Thursday, killing at least 26 people and wounding more than 50 ahead of provincial elections this weekend.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Opposition Activist Faces More Legal Trouble
item.description: Russian authorities on Thursday accused the political opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny and his brother, Oleg, of defrauding business associates of at least $125,000.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Court Allows Ex-Premier’s Candidacy
item.description: Pakistan’s High Court conditionally allowed former Prime Minister Raja Pervez Ashraf to run in general elections scheduled for May 11.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Dagestan Will Let Putin Choose Its Next Governor
item.description: Lawmakers in Russia’s Dagestan region voted Thursday to cancel popular elections for governor and allow President Vladimir V. Putin to choose its next leader.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: U.S. Selling Arms to Israel, Saudi Arabia and Emirates
item.description: A $10 billion deal would provide missiles, warplanes and troop transports to help Israel, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates counter threats from Iran.
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER
item.media:description: Chuck Hagel on Thursday before a meeting with Ban Ki-moon of the United Nations.

item.title: Warsaw Journal: Poland Reconnects to Jewish Past With Museum
item.description: Among civic leaders in Warsaw, a new Jewish museum is seen as a major step toward recognizing Poland’s Jewish past and recovering from its 20th-century traumas.
item.category: Museum of the History of Polish Jews
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:credit: Piotr Malecki for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wladyslaw Bartoszewski, an Auschwitz survivor, right, at the new Jewish museum in Warsaw.

item.title: Clapper Explains Spy Agencies Differ on North Korea
item.description: An assessment of North Korea’s nuclear capabilities was mistakenly declassified and released, but it did not reflect a consensus view, the director of national intelligence said.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: James R. Clapper Jr., the director of national intelligence, testifying on Thursday.

item.title: New Chemical Weapons Allegations in Syria Conflict
item.description: Britain and France have informed the United Nations that there is credible information suggesting that Syria’s government has used chemical weapons in the civil war, diplomats said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
International Committee of the Red Cross
United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: North Korea Tones Down Rhetoric Against U.S.
item.description: Security analysts in South Korea and the United States expressed cautious optimism that after weeks of threats, both sides might be ready to calm tensions.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: South Korean soldiers prepared 155-millimeter howitzers at military exercises on Thursday.

item.title: After Airstrike, Afghan Points to C.I.A. and Secret Militias
item.description: In critical remarks, a spokesman for the Afghan president said that an airstrike in which 12 children were killed was part of a C.I.A.-run operation.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: The graves of some of the 12 children killed in an airstrike in Kunar Province, in eastern Afghanistan, this month.

item.title: U.S. Indicts Guinea-Bissau’s Military Leader on Drug Charges
item.description: Gen. Antonio Injai was charged in New York on cocaine and weapons charges, part of an operation targeting top figures in a country long considered a major narco-state.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: India Ink: Universities Report 2013 Acceptance Rates
item.description: In our fourth listing of university admissions statistics, we include a three-year look at early, regular and overall acceptance rates at dozens of institutions in the United States.
item.dc:creator: By TANYA ABRAMS
item.media:description: to see our list of 2013 admission decisions at dozens of universities.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: The United States and Guns
item.description: Reporter Michael Luo tells Rendezvous’s editor, Marcus Mabry, that the Newtown shooting did change something in America, despite the defeat of gun control measures.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE

item.title: Italian Tax Police Seize Documents From JPMorgan in Milan
item.description: The seizure was part of the investigation into suspected fraud at Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena as a financial scandal widened.
item.category: Monte dei Paschi di Siena SpA
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Monetary Fund Chief Warns Against ‘3-Speed’ Recovery
item.description: Christine Lagarde, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, instead called for developing nations, the United States and Europe to move to a “full-speed” economy.
item.dc:creator: By ANNIE LOWREY
item.media:description: Christine Lagarde at the opening of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund's spring meetings in Washington this week.

item.title: World Briefing : Italian Lawmakers Fail to Elect a President
item.description: The center-left’s official candidate, Franco Marini, a former union leader and president of the Senate, was unable to get the two-thirds majority required.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Greek Foremen Sought in Attack on Migrant Workers
item.description: The three foremen on a strawberry farm are accused of firing on a large group of Bangladeshi workers who had demanded unpaid wages, wounding 28.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:description: A Bangladeshi worker inside his tent in the Greek town of Nea Manolada after the shooting incident on Wednesday.

item.title: Thatcher Funeral Draws Dignitaries and Complaints
item.description: The ceremonial funeral with military honors for Margaret Thatcher has divided British opinion, much as the former prime minister stirred passions in her lifetime.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II and her husband, Prince Philip, right, as they left the funeral for former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on Wednesday. Mrs. Thatcher’s son, Mark, shook the prince’s hand.

item.title: Merkel Concedes on Quotas for Women
item.description: Chancellor Angela Merkel found herself forced to give in to a rebellious bloc in her party that insisted Germany’s leading companies increase the number of women on their boards.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Competition Designed to Spread Basic Technologies
item.description: The World Bank is organizing a competition to find solutions that address access to technology in developing countries.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC PFANNER

item.title: Memoir of Amanda Knox to Be Released
item.description: In “Waiting to Be Heard,” Amanda Knox acknowledges her own mistakes and says she was the victim of mistreatment by Italian authorities while imprisoned over the murder of her roommate.
item.dc:creator: By JULIE BOSMAN
item.media:credit: Harpercollins, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Amanda Knox, an American, was convicted and then acquitted of murder in Italy.
